Oh, btw, grash54: you're ignorant in saying that a second is a second regardless of being 30fps or 25fps. Theoretically, it's true, except that when telecining 24fps film to NTSC (30fps) you can do that with some mixed frames and stuff, while doing telecining to PAL (25fps), the most used method is actually to speed up the 24fps to 25fps which means that the runtime is shorter. Don't believe this, just use Google. Cheers, and fuck off. :)

DolphWulff - FYI -> A telesync is a video copy of the movie which was shot in a cinema, often with a professional camera on a tripod in the projection booth, with a direct connection to the sound source (often FM audio provided for the hearing-impaired, or from a drive-in theatre). A telesync is a special type of cam that has the potential of better-quality audio and video. If the telesync is shot from within the projection booth there will be no keystone distortion (there will be keystone correction) of the video. Graph54.  Actually you made a fool of yourself, a Telesync is a cam simply plugged into the place for deaf people.  So the sound is ok, but the picture is totally CAM quality.

What you described, however is a TC or TeleCine. Not a TeleSync (TS).  TC is plugging direct into the projector to record your copy and its as good as any screener.  Your as bad as anyone else, not learning your formats, thus mislabeling the films constantly.  I really hate it when people confuse TC and TS and after all this time, Im amazed people are still confused about the obvious differences between the two.
Bad cam, subtitles of vampires cut off, crooked shot the whole way.  Not that a good copy would help this piece of crap movie.
